Heritage sites.Name: Dalemain Mansion & Historic Gardens
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: RHS Member: £0 Gardens, £4.50 Dalemain Mansion Tour
Heritage sites.Description: 14th-century country house features large gardens and hosts an annual marmalade festival. Dalemain is one of the most beautiful and impressive stately houses in the North West of England. The finely dressed pink stone of its Georgian façade glows magnificently in the sunlight. Yet hidden behind the ordered geometry of its Palladian architecture is the story of its past.

Heritage sites.Name: Dacre Castle
Heritage sites.Description: Dacre Castle is a moated tower house in the village of Dacre. It was constructed in the mid-14th century, probably by Margaret Multon, against the background of the threat of Scottish invasion and raids, and was held in the Dacre family until the 17th century.

Heritage sites.Name: Lowther Castle & Gardens
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: My Cumbria Card Holder - Two for one offer; Annual Passholder, Historic Houses Association, Royal Horticultural Society - Free; English Heritage£9.60
Heritage sites.Description: Imposing castle ruins, its gardens, cafe and shop, home to the Earls of Lonsdale in medieval times.

Heritage sites.Name: Aira Force Waterfall
Heritage sites.Open hours: during peak times (bank holidays, school holidays and sunny weekends) car parks are filling up by around 10am
Heritage sites.Description: An 18th-century pleasure ground, Aira Force was the backdrop for William Wordsworth’s poem ‘Somnambulist’ – a Gothic tale of love and tragedy. There are so many woodland trails to discover in this landscape of contrasts. Quiet glades give way to dramatic waterfalls, with Aira Beck thundering down a 65-foot drop past ferns and rocks.

Heritage sites.Name: Stock Ghyll Force
Heritage sites.Description: Scenic 70-ft. waterfall in a wooded area with a viewpoint & industrial heritage.

Heritage sites.Name: Armitt Library & Museum Centre
Heritage sites.Cost:
Adults £6 including gift aid
Students £4
Children (under 16) Free
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks:
Friends of the Armitt Free
Museum Association and Art Fund Members Free
Heritage sites.Description: Unusual museum, gallery and library devoted to the extensive cultural heritage of the Lake District.

Heritage sites.Name: The Bridge House
Heritage sites.Description: Tiny, whimsical 17th-century stone house, open for visits, on a bridge over Stock Beck River.

Heritage sites.Name: National Trust - Wray Castle
Heritage sites.Open hours: The grounds and Cafe are open, Castle temp closed
Heritage sites.Cost:
Adult £5.4
Child £2.7
Family £13.5
Entry to the grounds are free.
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: If you're not a National Trust (or National Trust for Scotland) member then you'll need to pay for parking.
Heritage sites.Description: Neo-gothic 1800s castle featuring a kid-friendly interior with play rooms, plus lakeside grounds.

Heritage sites.Name: Ambleside Roman Fort
Heritage sites.Open hours: Open any reasonable time during daylight hours
Heritage sites.Description: Set amid quiet farm fields, this area provides the remains of a Roman fort built in the 2nd century.

Heritage sites.Name: Holehird Gardens
Heritage sites.Description: Expansive hillside gardens featuring stunning landscaping & Victorian-style greenhouses.

Heritage sites.Name: Orrest Head Viewpoint
Heritage sites.Description: Miles Without Stiles 50: Orrest Head

Heritage sites.Name: Stagshaw Gardens
Heritage sites.Description: Tranquil woodland garden featuring walking paths through trees, shrubs & flowers.

Heritage sites.Name: Blackwell
Heritage sites.Cost:
Adult £9
Child (15+) £4.5
Child (4+) £0
Student £7
Family (1adult, 3children) £15.5
Family (2adults, 3children) £24.5
Heritage sites.Description: Large, late-19th-century house full of furniture and objects by Arts and Crafts movement designers.

Heritage sites.Name: Windermere Jetty Museum - Stories of boats and steam
Heritage sites.Cost:
Adult £9
Child (15+) £4.5
Child (4+) £0
Student £7
Family (1adult, 3children) £15.5
Family (2adults, 3children) £24.6
Heritage sites.Description: Family activities & displays of heritage boats at a lakeside museum with steam-launch tours.

Heritage sites.Name: Barkbooth Lot CWT Reserve
Heritage sites.Description: National reserve

Heritage sites.Name: Stott Park Bobbin Mill
Heritage sites.Description: Producer of bobbins for local industries, with original machinery and a Victorian steam engine. The story of the Bobbin Mill is brought to life with tours and an exhibition. Visitors can also see the journey from tree to bobbin first hand during production on the original belt driven machinery. A hands-on family trail with dressing up for children helps visitors to imagine what it was like to work at the mill.

Heritage sites.Name: Hill Top - Beatrix Potter's farmhouse home
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: Free entry for National Trust members
Heritage sites.Description: Beatrix Potter's 17th-century farmhouse: a time-capsule of her life

Heritage sites.Name: Beatrix Potter Gallery and Hawkshead
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: Free entry for National Trust members
Heritage sites.Description: Beatrix Potter's original artwork on display in a 17th-century house

Heritage sites.Name: Latterbarrow
Heritage sites.Description: Hill peak

Heritage sites.Name: Brantwood
Heritage sites.Cost: House and gardens,Adult £9.50, students£7.70, free for children (16 and under)
Heritage sites.Description: Former home of artist John Ruskin, now a house museum with period furniture, gardens & art displays.

Heritage sites.Name: National Trust - Tarn Hows
Heritage sites.Description: Popular, rustic nature area with walks around a picturesque lake bordered by conifer woods.

Heritage sites.Name: National Trust - Allan Bank and Grasmere
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: Free entry for National Trust members
Heritage sites.Description: Elegant 1800s villa & gardens once home to William Wordsworth, with a woodland walk & red squirrels.

Heritage sites.Name: Wordsworth Grasmere
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: Free entry available for Patrons and Friends of Wordsworth Grasmere, National Art Pass Holders
Heritage sites.Description: Former home of poet William Wordsworth, with a museum, guided tours, gardens & a tea room.

Heritage sites.Name: The Ruskin Museum
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: Free Entry for holders of the Museums Association card
Heritage sites.Description: Engaging collection with exhibits relating to John Ruskin and Donald Campbell, plus local heritage.

Heritage sites.Name: Ashness Bridge
Heritage sites.Description: Small stone packhorse bridge over a stream with picturesque lake views.

Heritage sites.Name: Bowder Stone
Heritage sites.Description: Enormous glacial rock resting at a seemingly precarious angle, with a metal staircase to the top.

Heritage sites.Name: Lodore Falls
Heritage sites.Description: Powerful falls with several drops over huge rocks, reached by a short path through a wooded valley.

Heritage sites.Name: Mirehouse & Gardens
Heritage sites.Cost:
House and gardens: Adult £9
Child £4
Family £24
Heritage sites.Description: Tranquil Cumbrian manor home with a park, plus strong literary and artistic connections.

Heritage sites.Name: Ravenglass Roman Bath House
Heritage sites.Description: Heritage building

Heritage sites.Name: Muncaster Castle
Heritage sites.Description: Muncaster has been owned by the Pennington family since the land was given to their ancestor Alan de Penitone in 1208. It’s grown from a medieval fortified tower-house or ‘pele’ tower, with many additions up to the late nineteenth century. Henry VI sought refuge here during the Wars of the Roses and left a glass drinking-bowl behind, saying if it remained unbroken the Penningtons would thrive. It’s still intact and is known as the ‘Luck of Muncaster’

Heritage sites.Name: Townend Farmhouse
Heritage sites.Location: South Westen Lake District, near Windermere
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: Free entry for National Trust members
Heritage sites.Description: This perfectly preserved seventeenth century house gives you a glimpse into the life of a comfortably-off farming family. It was built in 1626 for George Browne, a newly-married ‘statesman’ farmer, whose family continued to live here for over 300 years. The house was extended in the late 1600s, but has hardly changed since that time. It includes some beautiful carved furniture made for the Brownes

Heritage sites.Name: Sizergh Castle and gardens
Heritage sites.Membership body and perks: Free entry for National Trust members
Heritage sites.Description: Originally built by the Strickland family in c.1350, and then extended to become a grand Elizabethan residence, the Strickland family are still in residence. It houses an important collection of extremely rare carved oak furniture from the Elizabethan period along with portraits of the family through the years, managed by the National Trust parts of the castle and the gardens are open to visitors.

Heritage sites.Name: Rydal Mount House and Gardens
Heritage sites.Location: Central Lake District, between Ambleside and Grasmere.
Heritage sites.Description: Rydal Mount dates from the 16th Centuary and was William Wordsworth’s best loved family home from 1813 to his death in 1850 at the age of 80. The house continues to be owned by the Wordsworth family and retains the feel of a lived in family home, along with a 5 acre garden still in keeping with how William Wordsworth designed it. Rydal Mount has glorious views of Windermere, Rydal Water and the surrounding fells

Heritage sites.Name: Shap Abbey
Heritage sites.Description: These lonely ruins are the remains of the once-powerful Shap Abbey. Built around 1200, it housed a thriving monastic community. The church, chapter-house and living areas were grouped around a square cloister. Outside are traces of guest rooms, stables, workshops and the Abbey mill. Henry VIII closed the Abbey in 1540 and it slowly decayed. Some of its stone was used to build Shap Market Hall. Managed by English Heritage.

Heritage sites.Name: National Trust - Claife Viewing Station and Windermere West Shore
Heritage sites.Description: Built in the 1790s and later expanded,  Claife Viewing Station had windows tinted with coloured glass, designed to recreate the landscape under different seasonal conditions. Yellow created a summer landscape, orange an autumn one, light green for spring, dark blue for moonlight and so on.

Heritage sites.Name: Claife Heights
Heritage sites.Description: Claife Heights is an upland area in the Lake District, near to Windermere in Cumbria, England. It has a topographic prominence of 177 metres (581 ft) so is classified as a Marilyn (a hill with prominence of at least 150m).

Heritage sites.Name: Threlkeld Quarry & Mining Museum
Heritage sites.Open hours: Sun - Sat 10 am - 5 pm, with last admission at 4 pm.
Heritage sites.Cost:
The museum and train ride
Adults - £7.50   Children under 16 - £4.00
Heritage sites.Description: The Threlkeld Quarry and Mining Museum is located in Threlkeld three miles (4.8 km) east of Keswick, in the heart of the Lake District. It is suited for families, school classes, and enthusiasts. It includes a quarry with a unique collection of historic machinery, such as locomotives and cranes, an underground tour of a realistic mine, a comprehensive geological and mining museum, and mineral panning.

Heritage sites.Name: Galleny Force Waterfall
Heritage sites.Description: Galleny Force Waterfall is a great place for spending time outdoors for the whole family. The area around the force is known locally as Fairy Glen. It is a magical place, with plunge pools in deep gorges, and boulders and trees. Fairy Glen is one of the best spots for wild swimming in the Lake District.

Heritage sites.Name: Moss Force Waterfall
Heritage sites.Description: Moss Force is approximately 100 metres (328 ft) high, standing on Moss Beck which flows off the fell of Robinson. The Beck rises at a height of 540 metres, flowing across a boggy area known as Buttermere Moss before plunging down from a height of 420 metres in three distinct sections to form Moss Force. The top section, which is also the highest cascade, is split by an outcrop of rock and falls into a small pool surrounded by a few Rowan trees, then continues downwards through two smaller cascades. The middle cascade falls into a larger pool which has scattered Juniper around it. The bottom cascade is smallest of the three, after which the Beck enters a small wooded gorge containing further smaller falls. The Beck then levels out in the bottom of the Newlands Valley as it is joined by High Hole Beck and becomes Keskadale Beck.

Heritage sites.Name: Scale Force Waterfall
Heritage sites.Description: Scale Force is considered the highest waterfall in the English Lake District. The total height is 170 feet (51.8m). It lies on the stream Scale Beck. The waterfall (or force) is hidden in a deep gorge on the northern flank of Red Pike. It lies south of Crummock Water and is near the village of Buttermere.
